Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.raw_text: Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment is an implied promise that the tenant shall peaceably and quietly have and enjoy the leased premises, free from substantial interference by the landlord (or by conditions that the landlord is obligated to remedy).

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment is an implied promise that the tenant shall peaceably and quietly have and enjoy the leased premises, free from substantial interference by the landlord (or by conditions that the landlord is obligated to remedy).
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. Green v. Superior Court is a California Supreme Court decision about the implied warranty of habitability in California residential leases. While it briefly cites Massachusetts’ Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway for related ideas, it does not analyze or state the Massachusetts rule on the covenant of quiet enjoyment; its holding is about California’s implied warranty of habitability, not Massachusetts’ quiet enjoyment doctrine.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt:
“Moreover, the scarcity of adequate housing has limited further the adequacy of the tenant’s right to inspect the premises... Finally, the shortage of available low cost housing has rendered inadequate the few remedies that common law courts previously have developed to ameliorate the harsh consequences of the traditional ‘no duty to repair’ rule. 10”  

Footnote 10 then notes that constructive eviction expanded the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but this is in the context of California law and does not set out Massachusetts’ rule.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment is an implied promise that the tenant shall peaceably and quietly have and enjoy the leased premises, free from substantial interference by the landlord (or by conditions that the landlord is obligated to remedy).
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I..support_reasoning: This opinion is a Vermont Supreme Court decision about the implied warranty of habitability, not about Massachusetts law or the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment. The quoted portion where the court cites Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway is about recharacterizing leases as contracts and linking rent to habitability, not about defining Massachusetts’ covenant of quiet enjoyment or interference with use and enjoyment. Thus it does not establish or discuss the Massachusetts rule stated in the proposition.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (R.I..relevant_excerpt: “The modern view favors a new approach which recognizes • that a lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations. Thus, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is predicated on the landlord’s obligation to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition. Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 198, 293 N.E.2d 831, 842 (1973).”
